elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: INT. TARDIS — CORRIDOR
(FX: FADE UP. DOCTOR & CONSTANCE WALKING ALONG CORRIDOR.
CONSTANCE FOLLOWS DOCTOR TO HALT. DOCTOR OPENS A DOOR)
No...
FX: CLOSES DOOR. FOOTSTEPS TO HALT. OPENS ANOTHER DOOR
No...
FX: CLOSES DOOR. FOOTSTEPS TO HALT. OPENS ANOTHER DOOR
(FRUSTRATED) No!
FX: CLOSES DOOR
How can one possibly lose a kitchen? Loose change, keys, a purse, yes — but a kitchen?!
My dear Mrs Clarke, the TARDIS is alive and has a mind of its own. On occasion, its mind tends to wander.
It’s us doing the mindless wandering, it seems to me.
(IGNORING HER) Other side of the corridor, I think...
(FX: FOOTSTEPS TO HALT. OPENS ANOTHER DOOR. FROM WITHIN, SHRILL SHRIEKING AND BEATING OF LEATHERY WINGS — A MONSTER, COMING TOWARDS THEM)
Ah, I wondered where you’d got to!
FX: CLOSES DOOR, SHUTTING SHRIEKING OUT
Was that what I thought it was?
Probably not.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 3
FX: WALKING

You remind me of my Great-Uncle Jasper. Lived alone, rattling around in a huge, tumbledown pile in the country. He’d spend his days talking to the dog and taking pot-shots at rabbits through the breakfast room window.
That is nothing like me! I abhor guns, and as for rabbits — well, no creature can be that cute without an ulterior [motive] — (COMES TO HALT; MOCK-INDIGNATION) Great-Uncle? Great-Uncle?!
Oh! I didn’t mean — Come to think of it, how old are you, precisely?
FX: DOCTOR OPENS ANOTHER DOOR. BEAT
No. (SLAMS DOOR) Right, then — (CLAPS HANDS) Change of plan! I won’t be cooking dinner, we shall eat out!
Really, Doctor, I’m not hungry.

You’ve got used to that austerity diet, that’s all. The universe is our oyster, Mrs Clarke! No Ration Book necessary! Where do you fancy — Delmonico’s? The Grand Taverne des Londres? Tony and Helen’s Chip Bar?
Honestly, Doctor, I’m not in the least bit — [peckish]
FX: SUDDENLY, TARDIS LURCHES HORRIBLY
DOCTOR & CONSTANCE: (TOGETHER, AS THEY’RE THROWN ABOUT) Who-a-a-ahh!!
FX: EFFECT CALMS
What was that?
Emergency stop. Are you all right?
I’1ll live. I take it an evening of fine dining is no longer on the menu?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 4
(PULLING CONSTANCE TO HER FEET) Unfortunately not. Our next port of call is going to be —
FX: OPENS DOOR. CONTINUES INTO:
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 5
SCENE 2: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM [CONTINUOUS]
FX: STANDARD AMBIENCE
(FX: WALKING IN) .. the control room, good.
Wait a minute, wasn’t this several corridors back?
FX: THEY CROSS TO CONSOLE
Very probably. — Hmm. (FX: FLIPPING SWITCHES)
Is that a good ‘hmm’, or a bad ‘hmm’? What do all these lights indicate?
(DISTRACTED) We hit something, or rather something hit us.
(CURIOUS) Oh! Like a.. road traffic accident?
Not exactly. The TARDIS has been walloped by a whopping great pulse of Artron energy.
Meaning?

It’s a form of ambient radiation found in the time vortex. Fairly benign, but it can be used for any number of things, most notably as a power source. (FX: FLIPPING SWITCHES WITH GUSTO) Fortunately, it is obligingly easy to track!
FX: TARDIS VWORPS AWAY. CROSSFADE TO:
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 6
SCENE 3: INT. UNDERGROUND CHAMBER
(FX: TARDIS MATERIALISES, ECHOING AROUND CHAMBER. BEAT. DOOR OPENS )
(STEPPING OUT) Burnt Oak, Arizona. 2029. July the 13th. (CLOSES DOOR) A Sunday morning, I believe.
(HEARING ECHO) We’re underground.
It would appear so. (RUMMAGING IN POCKETS) One moment, I’m never without a torch.
‘Be prepared.’ Like a good Boy Scout?
Indeed. Let there be light! (FX: TORCH SWITCHED ON)
(AWE-STRUCK) Oh, my —
Curiouser and curiouser. This is quite the rabbit hole!
It’s a tomb...!
A tumulus, I'd say. A Viking burial barrow.
In the United States? In Arizona?
Quite the conundrum, isn’t it? (WALKING FORWARD) I count what, six, seven bodies? That chap on the dais in the middle must be their chieftain...
They’re exceptionally well-preserved. (THINKING) Arizona... I presume the desert heat must have baked them dry, over the centuries?
Very good, Constance.
Only it’s not been centuries since someone was in here last.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 7
I think you may be on to something. Footprints! Belonging to just one person, by the look of it. Small feet, too.
Oh, yes. But that’s not what I meant.
No?
Look here. The chieftain was clutching something to his chest. You can see the impression it made.
Something large, round and heavy. A shield would seem to fit the bill?
A shield, yes!
Well, whoever took it from our friend here was no reputable archaeologist. They were positively brutal in the way they removed it. See how the fingers were broken as they prised it free?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 8
SCENE 4: EXT. EXCAVATION SITE
FX: DA COSTA STRIDING OVER ROCKY SURFACE TO HALT
(CALLING UP) Bryce! Foreman Bryce! — Why’d you call me out here? It’s a Sunday, boy!
(NERVOUS) Major Da Costa, I — I’m sorry. It’s just some of the guys, they were saying, about this mound...
Mound? That’s a hill, Bryce. A hill. You’ve got eyes, right?
A hill, Major. If you’re sure. I wouldn’t want anyone getting into trouble, that’s al1l..
You know the schedule. You have your orders. Now level that
thing!
Roger that, Major!
FX: KEY IN IGNITION. BIG DIGGER STARTS UP
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 9
SCENE 5: INT. UNDERGROUND CHAMBER
Doctor, bring your torch over here.
You've found something else?
These runes, on the dais. I think I can read them...!
I thought that Modern Languages were your subject, Mrs Clarke.
I remember, at Bletchley: the Nazis once tried sending coded messages written in ancient Scandinavian script.
There you go. So you can translate.
That’s just it, Doctor. I didn’t work on that project. Only now I’m picking out fragments of phrases, mostly about ice, war and death.
No surprises there. Probably a chronicle of their journey. A saga of seafaring, beards and pickled herring.
(FX: FAINT RUMBLE AS BRYCE’S DIGGER BITES INTO THE WALL OF THE MOUND, OFF. CONTINUES THROUGH: )
(TOO ENGROSSED TO NOTICE) It’s getting clearer by the second. It reads like.. no, no, it feels like — like a warning of some sort. How I can say that, I’ve not the faintest idea.
I see what’s going on. Don’t worry, Constance, it’s just the TARDIS translation matrix tinkering with your perception.
The what tinkering with my what?
With your brain, essentially. Like I say, don’t worry about it.
This happened before, in the U-boat. I was speaking German, you said, but I heard English.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 10
It just sort of happens. A non-optional extra. I don’t know why you’re complaining, Mrs Clarke. Your body’s naturally awash with beneficial bugs and bacteria as it is, what’s one more in the mix?
Bugs?! What [bugs]
FX: CLOSER RUMBLE FROM APPROACHING DIGGER
Ssh, ssh! — Do you hear that? Not your stomach rumbling, is it?
I told you, I’m not hungry. — It’s like a tremor. It couldn’t
be an earthquake, could it?
Nonsense. It’s not in the ground. (GOING OVER) It seems to be coming from behind this wall...
FX: RUMBLING BUILDS. CONTENTS OF THE TOMB START TO CLATTER
(ALARM) It’s cracking!
What?
The wall, it’s bulging out!
So it is..!
Get back, there’s something [coming through! ]
(FX: RUMBLE BECOMES DEAFENING ROAR AS A MECHANICAL DIGGER TEARS OPEN ONE SIDE OF CHAMBER, SHOWERING THE DOCTOR IN EARTH)
Doctor! Doctor!!!
FX: CROSS TO POV OF BRYCE — DRIVING DIGGER
(OFF, TO BRYCE) Stop! Stop!!!
What the...?!
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 11
(OFF) Please, stop the machine!!!
Heck, yeah-!
(FX: BRYCE POWERS DOWN DIGGER. IT GRINDS TO A HALT. CLATTERS DOWN FROM DRIVER’S SEAT. FOLLOW HIM OVER TO CONSTANCE )
(CLAWING FRANTICALLY AT EARTH) My friend’s under here! Help me dig him out! —
S-sure..! (CALLING BACK) Major! Major Da Costa! Get the Major here now!!!
Who are you? What are doing here...?
Never mind that. Hold on, I think I can feel...
(MUFFLED UNDER EARTH) Ow!!!
I got a hand!
Then pull!!!
BRYCE & CONSTANCE:
EFFORT AS THEY HAUL DOCTOR OUT FROM UNDER CLODS OF EARTH
Doctor? Doctor, are you well?
(SPITTING EARTH AWAY) As well as any man who’s suffered the indignity of a premature burial.
Thank the Lord. I thought I’d killed you.
Lucky for me that you made such a hash of it, Mr, er...?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 12
Bryce. Foreman.
Tell me, Mister Bryce Foreman, do you make a habit of breaking open ancient archaeological sites with a ten-ton digger?
Never mind the goldfish act. — Constance, are you all right?
Perfectly well, I think. — Although I appear to have laddered my nylons, blast!
Never mind, no need to find a street corner spiv to replace them, not in 2029.
(APPROACHING FROM OUTSIDE) Bryce? What’s with all this constern— (BREAKS OFF, SEEING DOCTOR) Well, who the heck are these people?
Major Da Costa, sir!
Well?!
That’s the Doctor, and I’m Leading Wren Clarke.
(PROMPTING) ‘Major’.
Of course. (SALUTING) Leading Wren Clarke, C — sir!
I’m sorry, Major, but I almost ran these two down with the digger — sir!
What?
They were inside the hill when I opened it up.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 13
Say that again?
Why, that.. that’s right. They were inside it! I said, I knew it wasn’t just a hill...
Quiet!
It’s true, this is far more than a hill. Come in, Major, take a proper look around.
FX: DA COSTA STEPS PAST, VOICE ECHOING AS HE LOOKS AROUND
Well, I’1ll be damned!
I’1ll excuse the language, given the circumstances. Quite the discovery, isn’t it? An ancient tumulus. No longer intact, alas.
What were you doing here?
Wren Clarke and I were hoping to find a restaurant, but we appear to have got ourselves side-tracked, rather.
Rather. (ASIDE) Doctor, the way back to the TARDIS is blocked...!
(ASIDE) I know.
(CUTTING OVER) Okay, okay. Save it. You’re going to have to talk to the doctor. He’s in charge here.
What — then this is part of some scientific endeavour? Well, thank goodness. When I heard ‘Major’ I presumed, with tedious inevitability, that we were about to be locked up.
I was about to say — until the doctor gets here, I’1l have to lock you up.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 14
Strong arm tactics, the default setting of the military mind. You are a military man, Major?
Retired. But until I can determine that you’re not a threat, it’s my duty to protect everyone on this base.
Base, you say?
Foreman Bryce, call a guard to come and lock these people up.
Lock them up where, sir? We don’t have cells or nothing!
Secure storeroom. Just do it, Bryce!
(EXITING) Major!
(SOTTO) Doctor, what do we do now?
Now we get locked up. Why break the habit of six lifetimes?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 15
SCENE 6: INT. CAR/EXT. COMPOUND
FX: FADE UP. CAR IN MOTION
Here, driver. (FX: CAR PULLING OVER ONTO GRAVEL AND COMING TO
) (TO ZETTERLING) There’s Da Costa. This had
better be good, to make me forfeit my golf game.
You would have lost, anyway. You’re lousy at golf. Lousy at all sports, come to think of it. I don’t know why you bother. You know you don’t play well with others, Hugo.
Come on.
(FX: THEY OPEN PASSENGER DOORS AND GET OUT ONTO GRAVEL,
(APPROACHING) Doctor Macht. Professor Zetterling. Sorry to drag you out here at the weekend.
(CURT) Skip the pleasantries, Major.
(SHIVERS) Kinda chilly. — What have we got, Vincent?
Less than an hour ago we found two people inside the phase six site excavation. A man and a woman, [they —]
Whoa! Wait, wait, wait! Major, you’re supposed to be head of site security. How did two trespassers get that far inside the perimeter?
Sir, if you’1ll let me finish. They weren’t inside the facility, they were inside the excavation itself.
What...?
That low hill the crew was scheduled to level? It’s a tomb or something. There’s bodies, bones and relics all over the place... and a big blue box.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 16
Bodies?
Ancient. Like, really ancient.
The hill was dug open and, what? There they were?
That’s how Foreman Bryce tells it, ma’am.
(STRESSED) No, no, no! Not this. Not now!
(ASIDE) Hugo, take a breath.
(ASIDE) You take a breath, Lisa! It’s my money and my reputation on the line here! This is a multi-billion dollar investment. We go fully operational in six weeks with the whole world watching!
(ASIDE) All I’m saying is wait and see what’s happened. You might be worrying over nothing.
(ASIDE) Really? If that ‘hill’ proves to be a native American burial mound, the Department of the Interior’s going to have archaeologists and experts crawling all over it.
Yeah, maybe.
(ASIDE) They could hold up the program for months! Years! Instead of being the man who saved the world, I’ll bea laughing stock! Worse, I’11 be broke!
Uh, Dr Macht?
Yes!
The stuff we found didn’t look like native American remains to me. There were swords and helmets and... well, they kinda looked like Vikings.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 17
Vikings?
Like in that Two-D Kirk Douglas movie.
BEAT
BEGINS TO LAUGH) Vikings! Ha! (LAUGHS AGAIN
(PUZZLED) What’s so funny? It’s long been conjectured that Vikings made it to America. If this is for real, if this is hard evidence... it could re-write the history books!

But it won’t, because it’s a hoax. At least, that’s how we’ll Spin it if word gets out. A scheme cooked up by those eco- evangelical nut-jobs who reckon we should let Mother Earth heal herself rather than do it ourselves.
But if it’s genuine?
Who cares? We keep the site locked down, clear all non- essential personnel. The computer pretty much runs everything anyway. Once we’re up and running no-one will dare to try messing with us!
How can you be so sure?
Because, Professor Zetterling, I’ve built a career on knowing what people want. We’re saving the world, remember? Anyone who gets in our way is the bad guy in this!
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 18
SCENE 7: INT. SECURE STOREROOM
(SHIVERING) Why is it so cold in here? We’re in the Wild West. Cowboys, cacti and deserts.

Air-conditioning, Mrs Clarke. The human race does love messing about with its environment, for better or worse. They’d shift the world on its axis if they thought it would make them more comfortable. — Hence that monstrosity through the window.
(FX: PARTS WINDOW BLIND) I’ve never seen anything like it. It must be the size of St Paul’s.
As terraforming machines go it’s a modest effort. I’ve seen some the size of moons.
Yes, but what does it do, exactly?
Do you notice that gritty feeling between your teeth?
Now you mention it.. yes. Yes, I do.
Nanites. Self-replicating, microscopic robots. The geo-engine seeds the atmosphere with them in infinitesimal numbers.
(PUZZLED) What for?

Earth in this epoch is fighting a losing battle with climate change. Pollutants — like factory smog — are heating up the planet. Greenhouse gases are melting the ice caps and causing environmental collapse.
I presume that’s bad.
Catastrophic.
Well, can’t it be stopped?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 19

They’re trying. The nanites are an attempt to arrest the process by attacking the pollutants on a sub-atomic level. Scrubbing the sky clean. That gritty taste is the spent machines in the air. Completely harmless.
(SOMBRE) Oh, Doctor, what did we do?
Constance?
For it to come to this? The war, my war. The sacrifices we made so the future would be much brighter. Good men and women gave their lives and for what? So their heirs could poison the planet?
(SOFTLY) It does get better, I promise. Mankind does eventually realise its potential and spreads to the farthest reaches of the cosmos, right up until the end of time.
But there are still wars... and worse?
Two steps forwards, one step back. Things do improve though. The hand of man —
And woman.
And woman, will one day reach out and touch every star in the sky.
You’re certain?
I’ve seen it. Trust me.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 20
SCENE 8: INT. CORRIDOR
(FX: INTERIOR DOOR CLUNKS OPEN. 3 X FOOTSTEPS WALKING BRISKLY THROUGH, ALONG CORRIDOR)
Where are they?
Down here. I’ve locked them in one of the secure storerooms until we call in the Feds.
The Bureau?
Which we’re not going to. Not yet at least. I want to get a look at these people first. See what they have to say for themselves.
Can we even do that? Detain them?
FX: FOOTSTEPS TO HALT
Here we are. Sir. Ma’am.
Go ahead, Major.
FX: CROSS TO:
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 21
SCENE 9: INT. SECURE STOREROOM [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: DOOR UNLOCKED FROM OUTSIDE; SLIDES OPEN. BEAT
(LAUGHING) Well, now. What do we have here?
Ah! The mysterious ‘doctor’, I presume. — Makes a change for me to say [that.]
STILL SNIGGERING
(BREAKS OFF) Is something amusing you?
Aw, come on. No-one told me the circus had come to town! Did you get dressed in the dark or what?
Dr Macht, that’s not appropriate.
No, it isn’t.
Sorry, sorry. I let my mouth run off without engaging my brain sometimes. But, er, when I was told someone had been caught breaking into the facility — well, you two were not what I expected!
That’s reasonable.
I suppose so —
Kindly note, however, “Doctor”, that we didn’t “break in” anywhere!
Let’s try all that again, shall we? I’m Professor Zetterling, this is my boss Dr Macht, and Major Da Costa you know.
There, that’s better. — How do you do, Professor Zetterling. I’m the Doctor and this is my friend, Mrs Clarke.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 22
A doctor. Doctor of what?
Yeah, that’s what I was wondering.
Just... the Doctor.
Well, ‘just the Doctor’, you and Mrs Clarke here are in more trouble than you can care to imagine.
Oh, I don’t know. I can imagine quite a lot.
(ASIDE) That’s not helping.
How did you get in here undetected? Are there any others?
What are you, anyway? Gaia-nauts, or that monkey-wrenching Earth First outfit?
One at a time, please! — Mrs Clarke and I are travellers in time and space. We intercepted a significant burst of Artron energy in the time vortex and tracked it to this location.
(SCEPTICAL) Travellers?
Yes.
In time and space?
Correct.
Do you take us for morons?
‘Morons’ is a little strong, [but]
That’s enough, all of you!
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 23
Mrs Clarke here has a point. — “Doctor”, you need to do better than that.

You want proof of my credentials, Professor? Very well. The metallic tang we’re all tasting indicates elevated levels of expired nanite matter — short-circuited by the backwash from the Artron energy.
Y'know, I thought it was just me but I’ve been tasting metal all day!
Professor Zee?
(CAUGHT OUT) I... (HURRIEDLY; WITH “A SLIGHT ELEVATION IN HER BREATHING” — SEE SCENE 11) Nanite redundancies are only to be
expected. Nothing out of the ordinary.
Guess that’s you crashed and burned, Doc. So you watch the documentary channels. You know a bit of jargon. So what?
My ship, my TARDIS, is in the barrow. Take us there and I can prove it to you!
Your ship?
(SMILING) We might just go and do that. You two can stay here though. Professor, Major Da Costa?
FX: MACHT, ZETTERLING, DA COSTA EXIT THROUGH:
You can’t just leave us locked up!

(RUSHING TO FOLLOW) Professor Zetterling, I urge you to check for elevated levels of nanite wastage. As a scientist you know as well as I do the law of conservation of energy: energy cannot be destroyed but it can change form. Ergo, it is here, some-[where! ]
FX: DOOR SLIDES SHUT IN HIS FACE. CROSS TO:
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 24
SCENE 10: INT. CORRIDOR [CONTINUOUS]
FX: 3 X FOOTSTEPS WALKING.
Clever, very clever!
Care to share?
Coco the clown back there and his ‘friend’. They’re an elaborate distraction, that’s the only explanation. A sideshow to keep us looking the other way while their compatriots sabotage the geo-engine.
Sir, the computer’s visual recognition software logs and tracks all members of staff and visitors. Anyone not on the database is red-flagged immediately. It hasn’t happened.
(IRRITATED) So maybe they’re already on the system? Maybe we have a traitor? A sell-out?
Even so, it’s still quite a leap.
Well, how would you explain what they’re doing here?

All I know is you can’t simply throw a spanner in these works. The geo-engine is a hideously complex machine the size of a small mountain full of back-ups and self-maintaining systems. Even I don’t understand all of it.

(ANGRY) Then maybe they got someone smarter than you to mess with it? Did that occur to anyone? So go and do stuff, Lisa! Push buttons, pull levers, check it all out! (STORMING OFF) Why am I the only one who thinks of these things?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 25
SCENE 11: INT. SECURE STOREROOM
What a thoroughly irritating little man. ‘Watch the documentary channels‘, indeed! Let me assure you, [Constance]
Never mind Dr Macht. It was the Professor who interested me more.
She wasn’t much better.
No, she was hiding something.
Hiding something? When?
About these — what was it? Nanite redundancies. Couldn’t you see it?
Her body language, you mean?
I wouldn’t know about that. A slight elevation in her breathing, perhaps. A bit too quick to close the conversation.
You know, Constance, you may be on to something...!
Also, the footprints in the tomb. They were small, like mine.
A woman’s, you mean?
It’s possible. But why remove the shield from the Chieftain’s chest and say nothing about the barrow’s existence, even?
I haven’t the foggiest notion. Our priority has to be to get back to the TARDIS. Conduct our own analysis of the immediate atmosphere.
How? Bars on the window. A heavy lock on the door...
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 26
You forget, Mrs Clarke — this isn’t a cell, it’s a storeroom. So... (SEARCHING THROUGH CLINKING JARS & BOTTLES) .. there must be
something on these shelves to help us escape!
Doctor, it’s a food store!
Well, then — we’1ll just have to cook something up, won’t we?
What?
Trust me.
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 27
SCENE 12: INT. GEO-ENGINE CONTROL
(FX: FADE UP SOFTLY BLEEPING DATABANKS ETC. ZETTERLING CONCLUDES CLATTERING AT A KEYBOARD)
Done and done! — As you asked, Hugo, I’ve run a deep diagnostic of the primary and secondary systems — right down to the root code.
And?
All clean and green across the board.
(SCEPTICAL) So you’re saying there’s nothing to worry about. Nothing unusual occurring.
Absolutely not.
Look out the window, Lisa.
The window, w-[hy] (REALISATION) It... it’s snowing!
Started coming down a minute or two ago. Thought I’d let you finish first.
But it’s July!
Is it the geo-engine? The terraformer? Could it be making it snow?
Theoretically, yes...
I’d say it’s more than a theory now, wouldn’t you?
This is insane. There’s no test scheduled. According to my read-outs, nothing’s happening!
This is what I was talking about. This is sabotage, right here!
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 28
SCENE 13: EXT. TERRAFORMER FACILITY
FX: STRONG GUSTING WIND. HEAVY DOOR OPENS & CLOSES
Well, that was remarkably easy— (REALISATION) Doctor, it’s snowing!
Yes, the weather would seem to have taken an unexpected turn.
Snowing, in Arizona!
It’s not unknown. But unheard of in July. Look towards the horizon, what do you see?
That’s — that’s heat haze!
Now look up.
Thick grey clouds, right above us.
Not us. The terraformer.
That’s not a coincidence, is it?
(FX: OFF, MULTIPLE CAR DOORS OPENING AND CLOSING. CARS PULLING AWAY, DRIVING OFF, THROUGH: )
There are no coincidences.
Hello, what’s going on over there...?
(WELL OFF) Guys, come back! Guys! Think of your contracts! Guys...!
Looks like Mr Bryce Foreman is having staff trouble. The question is: is everyone nipping home to pick up a woolly jumper... or do they know something we don’t?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 29
SCENE 14: INT. GEO-ENGINE CONTROL
FX: AS BEFORE. ELECTRONIC DOOR SLIDES OPEN AND SHUT
(SHIVERING AND STAMPING FEET) Man alive, it’s cold out there! The morning starts out with an Arizona summer and the afternoon turns into a Wisconsin winter. No way that’s natural!
My thoughts exactly. Did you find anything, Major?
No, sir. I checked all the security logs, no unusual or suspicious activity.
Good. Now I want you to conduct interviews with the site staff and crew.
That’s.. gonna be hard.
What do you mean?
They’re leaving.
What?
Look out the window, Hugo. There’s a convoy. Everyone’s leaving.
They can’t just leave! — Major, get your guys to stop them!
My guys are leaving, too. (RELUCTANTLY) There’s been... talk.
What do you mean, talk?
Talk about levelling that mound. Lots of these men, they’ve got native American ancestors. Said it should have been left alone.
They’re saying — what, there’s a curse? Is that what you’re telling me?
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 30
That’s why Bryce called me in, he knew there was trouble brewin’. Then, when it started to snow...
Morons! — This is what I was talking about. Don’t you see, it’s all part of their plan!
Whose plan?
The saboteurs’!
Hugo, you’re starting to sound even more paranoid than usual.
Then no doubt I need to see a Doctor!
SNOWBLIND by Ian Edginton (003) Page 31
SCENE 15: EXT. TERRAFORMER FACILITY
(FX: DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE TRUDGING THROUGH BLIZZARD. HOWLING ARCTIC WIND) [NB: VOICES RAISED OVER WIND THROUGHOUT ]
Doctor, it’s getting worse! It’s a blizzard!
Well, now we know where the Artron energy went. It’s as I said, energy doesn’t disappear but it does change form!
